elements.content: The first three-connected, 5-fold interpenetrating network based on polyoxometalate building blocks and metal−organic frameworks that represents the highest degree of interpenetration presently known for 3D polyoxometalate systems is reported.
elements.clean_text: The first three-connected, 5-fold interpenetrating network based on polyoxometalate building blocks and metal-organic frameworks that represents the highest degree of interpenetration presently known for 3D polyoxometalate systems is reported.

elements.content: The first three-connected, 5-fold interpenetrating network based on polyoxometalate building blocks and metal−organic networks, which represents the highest degree of interpenetration presently known for 3D polyoxometalate systems, is reported.
elements.clean_text: The first three-connected, 5-fold interpenetrating network based on polyoxometalate building blocks and metal-organic networks, which represents the highest degree of interpenetration presently known for 3D polyoxometalate systems, is reported.

elements.content: Polyoxometalates (POMs) have been employed as inorganic building blocks for the construction of larger clusters or multidimensional (1D, 2D, and 3D) extended inorganic−organic hybrid frameworks, not only stemming from their numerous practical applications and remarkable range of physical properties but also from their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies. In recent years, a number of 1D, 2D, and even 3D polyoxometalate-based polymers have been successfully synthesized by Zubieta et al. and Pope et al. In the vast amount of reported work, the rational synthesis of high-dimensional polyoxometalate-based networks containing channel or voids is of particular interest. In contrast, the hybrid compounds containing polyoxometalates and organic ligands and/or metal−organic complexes have been unexploited to possess entangled character, although they have become an important class of inorganic−organic materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Polyoxometalates (POMs) have been employed as inorganic building blocks for the construction of larger clusters or multidimensional (1D, 2D, and 3D) extended inorganic-organic hybrid frameworks, not only stemming from their numerous practical applications and remarkable range of physical properties but also from their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies. In recent years, a number of 1D, 2D, and even 3D polyoxometalate-based polymers have been successfully synthesized by Zubieta et al. and Pope et al. In the vast amount of reported work, the rational synthesis of high-dimensional polyoxometalate-based networks containing channel or voids is of particular interest. In contrast, the hybrid compounds containing polyoxometalates and organic ligands and/or metal-organic complexes have been unexploited to possess entangled character, although they have become an important class of inorganic-organic materials.

elements.content: Entangled systems, one of the major themes of supramolecular chemistry, are common in biologyas seen in catenanes, rotaxanes, and molecular knotsand have attracted considerable attention because of their properties, aesthetic, and often complicated architectures and topologies. There are two comprehensive reviews by Robson and Batten of interpenetration, which has been the most investigated type of entanglement. Ongoing research in the coordination polymer has been directed toward the design and synthesis of novel entangled networks. On the basis of the study on topology of coordination polymer networks, we hope to obtain polyoxometalate-based compounds with fancy topology and interpenetrating character. To get the target complex, we choose the Keggin type anions as the building blocks to construct the network not only for the electronic, magnetic, photochemical, and catalytic properties but also for the stabilization in broad pH values as well as the strong coordination ability. The Keggin type anions could exist from an acidic to weak acidic environment. In the broad pH values, we can choose the suitable metal and ligands to construct POM-based high-dimensional interpenetrating networks. For charge balance, the N-donor ligands are more suitable than O-donor. The kind of ligand is an important factor for the structure of networks. Though many factors can influence the formation of the networks with interpenetrating character, such as the number and type of solvated molecules, the bulkiness of the ligands and the counterions, the presence of π−π interactions between aromatic bridging ligands, the coordination fashions, and so on, by and large, it can be said that the larger the voids in a three-dimensional net, the more likely interpenetration occurs and the more number of independent nets a particular void is passed through. Generally, longer ligands will lead to larger voids. To the best of our knowledge, 4,4‘-bipyridine, the rigid long organic ligand, has been proven to have a tendency to form networks with interpenetrating character. We choose the transition metal Cu(I) complex as the bridge to link the polyoxometalates together, forming a 3D network. In the vast number of reported networks with interpenetrating character, we could see that the larger the coordination number, the fewer interpenetrating networks. In a very loose and general sense, the coordination number is in inverse proportion to the probability of the interpenetrating. A series of studies on Cu(I) and Ag(I) in an entangled network have been discussed by Ciani and co-workers.

elements.content: Fortunately, by trial and error, we have now isolated a new compound, [(bpy)7CuI 7Cl2(PWVI 10WV 2O40)]·1.5H2O (bpy = 4,4‘-bipyridine) 1, that exhibitd an unprecedented 5-fold interpenetrated (6·102)2(6·102) topology, according to the aforementioned idea. Compound 1 was obtained as brown block by hydrothermal reaction of Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O, HCl, 4,4-bpy, Na2WO4·2H2O, and H3PO4 at 140 °C for 5 days.
elements.clean_text: Fortunately, by trial and error, we have now isolated a new compound, [(bpy)7CuI 7Cl2(PWVI 10WV 2O40)]⋅1.5H2O (bpy = 4,4‘-bipyridine) 1, that exhibitd an unprecedented 5-fold interpenetrated (6⋅102)2(6⋅102) topology, according to the aforementioned idea. Compound 1 was obtained as brown block by hydrothermal reaction of Cu(CH3COO)2⋅H2O, HCl, 4,4-bpy, Na2WO4⋅2H2O, and H3PO4 at 140 °C for 5 days.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis shows that compound 1 is a unique three-dimensional network constructed by coordination polymer layers and Keggin type anions as building blocks. Compound 1 contains four crystallographically unique Cu(I) centers, four bpy ligands, one Cl atom, and one Keggin type [PW12O40]5- anion (Figure ). For the single net, Cu1 and Cu4 exhibit identical coordination environments with two nitrogen atoms (Cu−N = 1.93(2)−1.98(3) Å) from the bpy molecules and one chlorine atom (Cu−Cl = 2.275(11)−2.475(11) Å); Cu3 shows a slightly distorted T geometry completed by two nitrogen atoms (Cu−N = 1.87(2)−1.93(2) Å) and one oxygen atom from polyoxometalate (Cu−O = 2.529(57) Å); Cu2 is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms (Cu−N = 1.89(3) Å) from the bpy molecules. Interestingly, two bpy ligands and three transition metal Cu atoms coordinate to form a remarkably long stick (Scheme ) whose dimension is 21.875 Å. The Cu···Cu···Cu angle is 174.4 or 180.0°. In compound 1, we could regard the Cu-bpy stick as a building block. First, two Cu-bpy sticks join together via two Cl atoms to form a small ring. The small rings are then linked through bpy molecules and the Cu-bpy sticks to construct layers. In the layers, except for the small rings, another big octagonal ring has been formed, which contains four long Cu-bpy sticks (two of them from the small rings), two bpy ligands, and two Cl atoms. The small rings and the big octagonal rings arrange alternately in the layers. Polyoxometalates act as bridges to link the layers to three-dimensional network via the middle Cu atoms of the Cu-bpy sticks in small rings (Figure ). Thanks to the Cu-bpy long sticks, the single network is porous. The pores show remarkable dimensions of 21.875 × 33.180 × 13.239 Å, which is necessary for interpenetrating to occur, as well as a much greater degree of interpenetration (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray analysis shows that compound 1 is a unique three-dimensional network constructed by coordination polymer layers and Keggin type anions as building blocks. Compound 1 contains four crystallographically unique Cu(I) centers, four bpy ligands, one Cl atom, and one Keggin type [PW12O40]5- anion (Figure ). For the single net, Cu1 and Cu4 exhibit identical coordination environments with two nitrogen atoms (Cu-N = 1.93(2)-1.98(3) Å) from the bpy molecules and one chlorine atom (Cu-Cl = 2.275(11)-2.475(11) Å); Cu3 shows a slightly distorted T geometry completed by two nitrogen atoms (Cu-N = 1.87(2)-1.93(2) Å) and one oxygen atom from polyoxometalate (Cu-O = 2.529(57) Å); Cu2 is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms (Cu-N = 1.89(3) Å) from the bpy molecules. Interestingly, two bpy ligands and three transition metal Cu atoms coordinate to form a remarkably long stick (Scheme ) whose dimension is 21.875 Å. The Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu angle is 174.4 or 180.0°. In compound 1, we could regard the Cu-bpy stick as a building block. First, two Cu-bpy sticks join  together via two Cl atoms to form a small ring. The small rings are then linked through bpy molecules and the Cu-bpy sticks to construct layers. In the layers, except for the small rings, another big octagonal ring has been formed, which contains four long Cu-bpy sticks (two of them from the small rings), two bpy ligands, and two Cl atoms. The small rings and the big octagonal rings arrange alternately in the layers. Polyoxometalates act as bridges to link the layers to three-dimensional network via the middle Cu atoms of the Cu-bpy sticks in small rings (Figure ). Thanks to the Cu-bpy long sticks, the single network is porous. The pores show remarkable dimensions of 21.875 × 33.180 × 13.239 Å, which is necessary for interpenetrating to occur, as well as a much greater degree of interpenetration (Figure ).

elements.content: If one consider three-coordinated Cu(I) centers to be three-connected nodes, the single net can then be rationalized as being a 3D net with slightly distorted T three-coordinate vertices (Figure ). The 3D network displays (6·102)2(6·102) (the first symbol for Cu1 and Cu4; the second for Cu3) topology and is 5-fold interpenetrating. For a single network, there are obvious six-membered rings in which each edge is parallel to the opposite edge, with node···node distances of 3.806, 10.920, and 10.915 Å. Six-membered rings are connected to form two-dimensional layers by sharing the four nodes located at the end of two long diagonals. The 2D layers are then linked via two nodes of the six-membered rings, which are located at the end of the short diagonals, to form a 3D network. The linkage among the six-membered rings results in the formation of 10-membered ring, which are bulkier than the six-membered ones. Each pair of opposite edges is also parallel. The two kinds of rings array alternately in a network (see the Supporting Information, Figure S3). Figure shows a representation of the fascinating entangled array in which each given (6·102)2(6·102) net is interpenetrated by four other independent, identical nets in a parallel manner. Note that the (6·102)2(6·102) net in 1 is “partially catenated”, meaning that only the larger 10-membered rings are catenated by others, leaving six-membered rings uncatenated. Each individual net is translated along the a-axis by 1/5 of the window height.
elements.clean_text: If one consider three-coordinated Cu(I) centers to be three-connected nodes, the single net can then be rationalized as being a 3D net with slightly distorted T three-coordinate vertices (Figure ). The 3D network displays (6⋅102)2(6⋅102) (the first symbol for Cu1 and Cu4; the second for Cu3) topology and is 5-fold interpenetrating. For a single network, there are obvious six-membered rings in which each edge is parallel to the opposite edge, with node⋅⋅⋅node distances of 3.806, 10.920, and 10.915 Å. Six-membered rings are connected to form two-dimensional layers by sharing the four nodes located at the end of two long diagonals. The 2D layers are then linked via two nodes of the six-membered rings, which are located at the end of the short diagonals, to form a 3D network. The linkage among the six-membered rings results in the formation of 10-membered ring, which are bulkier than the six-membered ones. Each pair of opposite edges is also parallel. The two kinds of rings array alternately in a network (see the Supporting Information, Figure S3). Figure  shows a representation of the fascinating entangled array in which each given (6⋅102)2(6⋅102) net is interpenetrated by four other independent, identical nets in a parallel manner. Note that the (6⋅102)2(6⋅102) net in 1 is "partially catenated", meaning that only the larger 10-membered rings are catenated by others, leaving six-membered rings uncatenated. Each individual net is translated along the a-axis by 1/5 of the window height.

elements.content: The IR spectra of compound 1 (see the Supporting Information, Figure S1) exhibits a broad band at 3454 cm-1 associated with the water molecules. The features at 1612, 1420, 1491, and 1532 cm-1 are assigned to the bpy molecules. The compound also possesses a strong band at 1101 cm-1 that is attributed to v(P−O) and bands at 948 and 891 cm-1 that are attributed to v(W−O) and v(W−O−W).
elements.clean_text: The IR spectra of compound 1 (see the Supporting Information, Figure S1) exhibits a broad band at 3454 cm-1 associated with the water molecules. The features at 1612, 1420, 1491, and 1532 cm-1 are assigned to the bpy molecules. The compound also possesses a strong band at 1101 cm-1 that is attributed to v(P-O) and bands at 948 and 891 cm-1 that are attributed to v(W-O) and v(W-O-W).

elements.content: The TG curve of compound 1 (see the Supporting Information, Figure S2) exhibits two weight-loss stages. The first step in the temperature range 160−240 °C corresponds to the loss of 1.5 composed waters. The second step in the temperature ranges 340−560 and 650−800 °C corresponds to the loss of 4,4‘-bpy (six first and one later). Compound 1 is steady below 340 °C.
elements.clean_text: The TG curve of compound 1 (see the Supporting Information, Figure S2) exhibits two weight-loss stages. The first step in the temperature range 160-240 °C corresponds to the loss of 1.5 composed waters. The second step in the temperature ranges 340-560 and 650-800 °C corresponds to the loss of 4,4‘-bpy (six first and one later). Compound 1 is steady below 340 °C.

elements.content: In summary, we have prepared and characterized the first 5-fold interpenetrated (6·102)2(6·102) net based on polyoxometalates and containing only three-coordinate nodes by using a linear rigid N-donor ligand and transition metal Cu, which form remarkably long sticks, making it an interesting member of three-connected interpenetrating networks; this represents the highest degree of interpenetration presently known for polyoxometalate systems. The current work also indicates that the polyoxometalates could be introduced to network with entangled character.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have prepared and characterized the first 5-fold interpenetrated (6⋅102)2(6⋅102) net based on polyoxometalates and containing only three-coordinate nodes by using a linear rigid N-donor ligand and transition metal Cu, which form remarkably long sticks, making it an interesting member of three-connected interpenetrating networks; this represents the highest degree of interpenetration presently known for polyoxometalate systems. The current work also indicates that the polyoxometalates could be introduced to network with entangled character.

References

cln_elements.content:
Fortunately, by trial and error, we have now isolated a new compound, [(bpy)7CuI 7Cl2(PWVI 10WV 2O40)]·1.5H2O (bpy = 4,4‘-bipyridine) 1, that exhibitd an unprecedented 5-fold interpenetrated (6·102)2(6·102) topology, according to the aforementioned idea. Compound 1 was obtained as brown block by hydrothermal reaction of Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O, HCl, 4,4-bpy, Na2WO4·2H2O, and H3PO4 at 140 °C for 5 days.

The TG curve of compound 1 (see the Supporting Information, Figure S2) exhibits two weight-loss stages. The first step in the temperature range 160−240 °C corresponds to the loss of 1.5 composed waters. The second step in the temperature ranges 340−560 and 650−800 °C corresponds to the loss of 4,4‘-bpy (six first and one later). Compound 1 is steady below 340 °C.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Fortunately, by trial and error, we have now isolated a new compound, [(bpy)7CuI 7Cl2(PWVI 10WV 2O40)]⋅1.5H2O (bpy = 4,4‘-bipyridine) 1, that exhibitd an unprecedented 5-fold interpenetrated (6⋅102)2(6⋅102) topology, according to the aforementioned idea. Compound 1 was obtained as brown block by hydrothermal reaction of Cu(CH3COO)2⋅H2O, HCl, 4,4-bpy, Na2WO4⋅2H2O, and H3PO4 at 140 °C for 5 days. 

The TG curve of compound 1 (see the Supporting Information, Figure S2) exhibits two weight-loss stages. The first step in the temperature range 160-240 °C corresponds to the loss of 1.5 composed waters. The second step in the temperature ranges 340-560 and 650-800 °C corresponds to the loss of 4,4‘-bpy (six first and one later). Compound 1 is steady below 340 °C.

metadata.title:
An Unprecedented Fivefold Interpenetrating Network Based on Polyoxometalate
Building Blocks
